name: Diaspora Yeshiva Band
description: The '''Diaspora Yeshiva Band''' ({{langx|he|להקת ישיבת התפוצות}}) was an American-Israeli [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] [[Jewish rock]] band founded at the Diaspora Yeshiva on [[Mount Zion]], [[Jerusalem]], by ''[[baal teshuva]]'' students from the United States. In existence from 1975 to 1983, the band infused [[Rock music|rock]] and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] music with Jewish lyrics, creating a style of music it called "Chassidic rock"{{sfn|Tilbury|1989|p=193}} or "Country and Eastern". The band had an international following, having become famous  after winning three Israel Chassidic Festivals, in 1977, 1978, and 1980 and produced many  hit songs. They were very popular with Jewish Youth Groups and tourists in the early to mid-1980s, and became very well known in Jerusalem for their Saturday-night concerts at [[David's Tomb|King David Tomb]]. DYB had a considerable influence on [[contemporary Jewish religious music]], inspiring later bands such as [[Blue Fringe]], [[8th Day (Jewish band)|8th Day]], [[Reva L'Sheva]], [[Soulfarm]], the [[Moshav (band)|Moshav Band]], and [[Shlock Rock]]. Fifteen years after it disbanded, band leader Avraham Rosenblum revived the band under the name '''Avraham Rosenblum & Diaspora''' and produced several more albums.
